articles.description:
LONDON, Sep 15 (IPS) - With hope and courage, we must rise to the challenges before us. We must rise to the challenge of a world set afire by climate change, forced displacement, armed conflicts and human rights abuses. We must rise to the challenge of girls being denied their right to an education in Afghanistan. We must rise to the challenge of a global refugee crisis that is disrupting development gains the world over. We must rise to the challenge of brutal and unconscionable wars in places like Sudan and Ukraine that are putting millions of children at risk every day.

Read the full story, “The Vast Potential of the Human Spirit”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Vast Potential of the Human Spirit

Saudi Arabia must immediately revoke the death sentence handed down to Mohammed Al Ghamdi for posting critical views online, as the crackdown on freedom of expression in the country continues to escalate, independent UN human rights experts said on Friday.

Read the full story, “Time to revoke death penalty for social media dissent, UN experts urge”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Time to revoke death penalty for social media dissent, UN experts urge

articles.description:
MEXICO CITYhttps://ipsnoticias.net/2023/09/mexico-gira-hacia-los-militares-empresarios/, Sep 14 (IPS) - Courage, sadness and impotence are expressed by Mayan indigenous activist Sara López when she talks about the Mayan Train (TM), the Mexican government's biggest infrastructure project, which will cross the town where she lives and many others in the Yucatan Peninsula.

Read the full story, “Mexico Turns to Military Entrepreneurs”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Mexico Turns to Military Entrepreneurs

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: A plane crash in Brazil's northern Amazon state on Saturday has left 14 dead, the state's governor said.The accident took place in the Barcelos province, some 400 km (248 miles) from the state capital, Manaus.
articles.title: Plane crash in Brazil's Amazon state leaves 14 dead

articles.description: Several Republican presidential hopefuls, including Mike Pence and Ron DeSantis, are set to address an influential gathering of Iowa evangelical Christians. They hope to sway support from former President Donald Trump, who is skipping the event. Trump, despite not attending such gatherings, maintains popularity among evangelical Christians and social conservatives due to his stance on issues such as abortion.
articles.title: Donald Trump skips Iowa gathering of evangelical Christians. His rivals hope for a chance to gain ground

articles.description: Ukrainian President Volodymr Zelenskyy has welcomed the European Commission's decision to lift restrictions on Ukraine's agricultural exports to the EU. Zelenskyy emphasized the importance of European unity on a bilateral level. The European Commission had temporarily banned the export of wheat, maize, rapeseed, and sunflower seeds from Ukraine due to concerns about local farmers being undercut by cheap Ukrainian grain.
articles.title: EU ends restrictions against Ukraine's agricultural exports, Zelenskyy welcomes move

articles.description: Much of Westminster sniggered earlier this month when Rishi Sunak branded Keir Starmer “Captain Hindsight.” But the meme-ready moniker gives away more than a little about the UK prime minister’s plan to save his job: Don’t look back. Barrel ahead. Hope for the best.
articles.title: 'Don’t look back': How UK PM Rishi Sunak plans to save his job

articles.description: EU chief Ursula von der Leyen will visit the Italian island of Lampedusa this weekend with Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni in response to a surge in migrant arrivals. Over 8,500 people landed on Lampedusa over three days this week, putting pressure on the island's resources. The visit comes as officials transferred thousands of migrants to Sicily and sparked a debate on Europe's responsibility for asylum seekers.
articles.title: EU chief to visit Italian island after migrant surge

articles.description: An investigation has been launched into the collapse of two dams in Derna, Libya, which caused a deadly flood that killed over 11,000 people. The floods were caused by heavy rains brought on by storm Daniel. Rescue teams are still searching for bodies and survivors, but more than 10,000 people are still missing. Aid efforts are ongoing, with concerns about waterborne diseases and explosive ordnance.
articles.title: Libya probes the collapse of two dams after flood devastated an eastern city, killing over 11,000

articles.description: The British government has announced an increase in visa fees, effective from October 4. The cost of a visit visa for under six months will rise by GBP 15, and student visas will be GBP 127 more expensive for travelers from around the world. The changes are aimed at meeting the country's public sector wage increase and are expected to raise over GBP 1 billion. The fee increase applies to various visa categories and is subject to parliamentary approval.
articles.title: UK visa fee hike for visitors, students to be effective from October 4
Pakistan Air Force carries out flying exercises in China, Egypt

articles.description: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has filed a petition in the Islamabad High Court seeking post-arrest bail in the cipher case. Khan has requested bail until the final disposal of the case, stating that there are nearly 200 criminal cases registered against him, including charges of corruption and murder.
articles.title: Imran Khan files petition in Islamabad court, seeks post-arrest bail in cipher case

articles.description: Hurricane Lee is heading towards New England and eastern Canada, causing storm watches and warnings. Cruise ships have sought refuge in Portland, Maine, while lobstermen in Bar Harbor have pulled their traps from the water and moved their boats inland. States of emergency have been declared in Massachusetts and Maine.
articles.title: Millions under storm watches and warnings as Hurricane Lee bears down on New England and Canada

articles.description: Aid groups warned of growing risk posed by the spread of disease that could compound the humanitarian crisis in Libya, as hopes dwindled Saturday of finding more survivors days after deadly flooding. Islamic Relief warned of a "second humanitarian crisis" after the flood, pointing to the "growing risk of water-borne diseases and shortages of food, shelter and medicine".
articles.title: Aid groups sound alarm in Libya as hopes fade for flood survivors

articles.description: Moscow has dismissed as "politically motivated" the conviction of Russian businessman Vladislav Klyushin in a US court for participating in a $93 million insider-trading scheme, the state news agency RIA reported on Saturday.
articles.title: Russia says US conviction of Kremlin-linked businessman 'politically motivated': RIA

articles.description: Two Russian cosmonauts and an astronaut from the United States have docked with the International Space Station (ISS) after taking off from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan amid raging tensions between Moscow and Washington over the invasion of Ukraine, Al Jazeera reported.
articles.title: Russian Soyuz with two cosmonauts, one US astronaut docks at International Space Station

articles.description: Pakistan's caretaker government has announced another increase in the prices of petrol and diesel, bringing them to a historic high of over Rs 330 per litre. This comes amidst double-digit inflation in the country. The fuel price hike follows a 27.4% increase in the rate of inflation in August, putting a burden on the masses.
articles.title: Fuel prices in Pakistan smash records after caretaker government announce another hike

articles.description: The Taliban authorities in Afghanistan have detained 18 staff members of a Swiss-registered NGO, including a foreigner. The International Assistance Mission (IAM), which has been operating in Afghanistan since 1966, said the staffers were taken from its office in Ghor province and brought to Kabul. The nature of the allegations against the staff members is currently unknown.
articles.title: Swiss NGO says 18 staff members detained in Afghanistan

articles.description: Pakistan's Sui Northern Gas Pipelines Limited (SNGPL) has disconnected 241 gas connections in Punjab, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, and Islamabad, imposing a fine of Rs 2.7 million. The disconnections were made due to illegal gas usage, meter tampering, and compressor usage. SNGPL teams discovered illegal gas connections and networks in various cities and imposed fines on the violators.
articles.title: Pakistan: Sui Northern Gas Pipelines Ltd disconnects 241 gas connections

articles.description: Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu showed North Korean leader Kim Jong Un Russia's hypersonic 'Kinzhal' missiles and strategic bombers on Saturday, according to Interfax. When Kim arrived at Russia's far eastern Primorsky area, Shoigu showed him three strategic bombers: the Tu-160, Tu-95, and Tu-22M3.
articles.title: Russia shows North Korea's Kim hypersonic missiles and strategic bombers

articles.description: Teachers at Karachi University in Pakistan have boycotted evening classes in protest against the non-payment of their remuneration, which has been withheld for over a year. The teachers were told by the vice-chancellor that if they were not paid, they could stop taking the classes. The teachers unanimously decided to boycott the classes indefinitely.
articles.title: Pakistan: Karachi University teachers boycott evening classes over non-payment of remuneration

articles.description: A unit of China's Rocket Force uncovered "shortcomings" during a field assessment of an exercise, the PLA Daily - the official newspaper of the Chinese military - reported on Friday in a rare critique. It suggested gaps in combat readiness at the armed force overseeing conventional and nuclear missiles.
articles.title: Rocket force not combat-ready: PLA paper in rare critique

articles.description: China is sending vice-president Han Zheng to the UN General Assembly's annual summit, the ministry of foreign affairs said Friday, suggesting that the country's most senior diplomat, Wang Yi, will not attend. This year's gathering at UN headquarters in New York starts Monday.
articles.title: Foreign minister to skip UNGA, veep to attend session in New York

articles.description: Apple pledged on Friday to update software on iPhone 12s in France to settle a row over radiation levels, but concerns in other European countries signalled it may have to take similar action elsewhere. France this week suspended sales of iPhone 12 handsets after tests which it said found breaches of radiation exposure limits.
articles.title: Apple to update iPhone 12 in France after radiation row

articles.description: Iran has seized two oil tankers allegedly carrying smuggled fuel in the Gulf and arrested their crews, state television announced on Friday. "The Revolutionary Guards naval forces seized two ships over the course of the last two days," state television said, citing Mohammad-Sharif Shirali, a Guards commander. "
articles.title: Iran seizes two foreign tankers for 'smuggling'

articles.description: Libyan authorities limited access to an inundated city on Friday to allow searchers to dig through mud and hollowed-out buildings for 10,000 people missing and feared dead in flooding that has already killed more than 11,000. Authorities warned that disease and explosives shifted by the waters could claim yet more lives.
articles.title: Search teams look for 10,000 missing in flooded Libyan city after toll tops 11,000

articles.description: In the midst of the 1979 Iran hostage crisis, the CIA began what came to be noted as one of the spy agency's most successful publicly known operations: the rescue of six American diplomats who had escaped the overrun US embassy - using a fake movie as the cover story.
articles.title: Ben Affleck played lone hero in 'Argo'. CIA now reveals identity of 2nd spy in op

articles.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy  will visit Washington next week to solidify support from the US in fighting Russian invaders. Zelenskyy will meet with President Joe Biden and hold meetings at the US Congress. The visit comes at a critical time as Ukraine wages a counteroffensive against Russia. Biden will reaffirm his commitment to supporting Ukraine's independence and territorial integrity.
articles.title: Zelensky to make second wartime White House visit to rally support

articles.description: The Dominican Republic shut all land, air and sea borders with Haiti on Friday in a dispute about construction of a canal on Haitian soil that taps into a shared river, as armed Dominican soldiers patrolled entry points and military planes roared overhead.
articles.title: Dominican Republic closes all borders with Haiti as tensions rise in a dispute over a canal

articles.description: Federal prosecutors are seeking an order that would prevent Donald Trump from making “inflammatory” and “intimidating” comments about witnesses, lawyers and other people involved in the criminal case charging the former president with scheming to overturn the 2020 presidential election.
articles.title: Prosecutors seek narrow gag order on Trump in DC elections case after 'inflammatory' public comments

articles.description: Pakistan on Friday announced a record rise in petrol and diesel prices, the second big increase in two weeks for the South Asian nation that is already struggling with high inflation.
articles.title: Pakistan raises petrol, diesel prices by record amount

articles.description: The Kasbah La Dame Bija guesthouse in Morocco's picturesque Ouirgane Valley escaped unscathed from an earthquake that devastated the area, but the owner's bookings collapsed and he worries about whether the region can revive its tourist appeal.
articles.title: Moroccans in earthquake-hit tourist area grieve losses, fret about future

articles.description: KABUL: The Taliban have detained 18 staffers, including a foreigner, from a nongovernmental organisation based in Afghanistan, the nonprofit group sai.
articles.title: Taliban have detained 18 staff, including a foreigner, from an Afghanistan-based NGO, it says

articles.description: President Joe Biden has announced new sanctions on individuals in Iran responsible for human rights abuses, as the US marks the anniversary of the death of Mahsa Amini. Amini died while in police custody after being detained for allegedly wearing her hijab too loosely.
articles.title: Biden announces more Iran sanctions on the anniversary of Mahsa Amini's death

articles.description: The United Nations' World Heritage Committee has added two historical sites in Ukraine to its list of endangered sites. The St. Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv and the medieval center of Lviv are UNESCO World Heritage Sites that are important to Ukraine's culture and history. While neither site has been directly targeted in the ongoing conflict with Russia, the decision to list them as endangered could help deter further attacks.
articles.title: UNESCO puts 2 locations in war-ravaged Ukraine on its list of historic sites in danger

articles.description: Lampedusa, an Italian island nestled in the Mediterranean between Tunisia, Malta, and the larger Sicilian island, is grappling with an unprecedented migrant crisis. ​​​​In the span of a week, approximately 7,000 migrants have arrived, surpassing the island's permanent residents and straining its capacity to provide adequate assistance.
articles.title: Why are Italians upset with Giorgia Meloni

articles.description: A group of would-be protesters in Sarajevo are shouting and blowing whistles at the EU force's camp, in a demonstration reminiscent of recent protests by Bosnian Serbs. The EUFOR is currently conducting an exercise called "Quick Response 2023" to test its ability to rapidly activate and integrate reserve troops. The commander of EUFOR, Helmut Habermayer, emphasized the importance of adapting forces in volatile times, but also stated that military force is always the last resort.
articles.title: EU troops confront would-be rioters in exercise echoing Bosnia political crisis

articles.description: Lithuania's President Gitanas Nauseda has revoked retired Olympic figure skater Margarita Drobiazko's Lithuanian citizenship due to her support for Russia. Drobiazko, who was born in Moscow and represented Lithuania in five Olympic Games, has been accused of breaking her oath and discrediting Lithuania by cooperating with Russia. Last year, Nauseda also stripped Drobiazko and her partner of Lithuanian state decoration after they performed in a skating show in Russia.
articles.title: Lithuania strips citizenship from retired Olympic ice skater for support for Russia

articles.description: Iranian security forces have been deployed in the hometown of Mahsa Amini ahead of the first anniversary of her death in police custody, according to witnesses and rights groups. Amini's death sparked widespread anti-government protests, with over 500 people killed and thousands arrested. Security forces have reportedly been stationed in several cities, and surveillance cameras have been installed to monitor potential protesters. Internet connectivity has also been disrupted in some areas.
articles.title: Heavy security in Iran on Mahsa Amini death anniversary -rights groups, witnesses

articles.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited an aircraft factory in Russia, where he inspected the country's most advanced fighter jet, the Su-57. This visit has raised concerns about potential banned weapons transfer deals between the two countries. Kim's trip to Russia, which includes meetings with President Vladimir Putin and visits to weapons and technology sites, highlights the deepening ties between the two nations.
articles.title: North Korea's Kim gets a close look at Russian fighter jets as his tour narrows its focus to weapons

articles.description: The Pakistan-Afghanistan Torkham border has been reopened after eight days of closure. The decision to resume movement on the trade border was made by both countries. Tensions between the Pakistan and Afghanistan Army have subsided, allowing vehicular and foot traffic to resume. Vehicles are being allowed to cross the border after clearance, and people who were stuck for over a week are also permitted to crossover after strict inspection.
articles.title: Pakistan, Afghanistan Torkham border reopens after eight days of closure

articles.description: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has announced plans to ban American XL Bully dogs, describing them as a "danger to our communities." The breed is not currently recognized as a breed in the UK, but Sunak has asked for a legal definition to be established. The government has faced pressure to take action after recent attacks, including one in which an 11-year-old girl was seriously injured.
articles.title: After attacks, British prime minister says American XL Bully dogs are dangerous and will be banned

articles.description: Northeastern University in the US has decided to award a posthumous master's degree to Indian student Jaahnavi Kandula, who tragically died after being hit by a speeding police car. The degree will be presented to her family from Andhra Pradesh. The university's Chancellor expressed solidarity with the Indian student community and condemned the insensitive remarks made by a Seattle police officer regarding the incident.
articles.title: Indian student Jaahnavi Kandula to get master's degree posthumously

articles.description: Rescue teams have arrived from Egypt, Tunisia, the UAE, Turkiye and Qatar.
articles.title: Political fractures hinder global aid

articles.description: The coastal city of Derna in Libya experienced severe flooding after two dams burst, leaving thousands of people displaced and searching for loved ones. Many residents were caught off guard by the flooding as there were no evacuation plans in place. The devastation caused by the floodwaters resulted in the loss of lives and destruction of buildings.
articles.title: Caught unaware, whole families drowned in a matter of minutes

articles.description: Libyan authorities have called for an investigation into the cause of the devastating floods that have resulted in thousands of deaths in the country. The floods were triggered by a powerful storm that caused dams to burst, washing away buildings and trapping people inside. The death toll is estimated to be in the thousands, with many more people missing.
articles.title: Libya seeks answers as flood deaths feared to cross 20,000

articles.description: Nasa has released findings from its yearlong study into UFOs, stating that the study of these unidentified flying objects will require new scientific techniques and a shift in perception. The study's 33-page report cautions that the negative perception surrounding UFOs hampers data collection. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson aims to shift the conversation from sensationalism to science and reduce the stigma around UAPs (unidentified anomalous phenomena).
articles.title: Nasa says more science and less stigma are needed to understand UFOs

articles.description: The Pentagon has clarified that it has not restarted counterterrorism operations in Niger, despite earlier reports. Gen. James Hecker had stated that some manned aircraft and drone operations had resumed, but the Pentagon clarified that these missions were only for protecting US forces and not broader counterterrorism operations.
articles.title: Pentagon says surveillance flights, not counterterrorism ops, have restarted in Niger

articles.description: President Joe Biden challenged his Republican opponents by arguing that his management of the economy has been better than former President Donald Trump's. He accused Republicans of undermining working-class Americans and criticized their plans to cut taxes for the wealthy and make savings from Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.
articles.title: Joe Biden accuses Republicans of undercutting working-class Americans

articles.description: China conducted large-scale military drills in the Western Pacific, deploying an aircraft carrier and numerous naval ships and warplanes as a display of power against US pressure. The exercises took place after the U.S. conducted military drills with allies in the region. China's aircraft carrier, along with missile destroyers, frigates, and supply ships, were spotted in waters near Japan, Taiwan, and the Philippines.
articles.title: China conducts major military exercises in Western Pacific

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet Elon Musk during his upcoming trip to the United States. The meeting, scheduled for Monday, will focus on discussions about artificial intelligence. This comes as Musk faces accusations of allowing antisemitic messages on his social media platform, X. The Anti-Defamation League has accused Musk of amplifying hate speech, but Musk has denied these claims.
articles.title: Israel's Benjamin Netanyahu is to meet Elon Musk. Their sit-down comes as X faces antisemitism controversy

articles.description: China has increased its military exercises near Taiwan, scrambling 68 military aircraft and sending 10 navy vessels into the area. The Chinese fleet, including the Shandong aircraft carrier, was detected about 60 nautical miles southeast of Taiwan. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has been pressuring the island through military and political means.
articles.title: Taiwan detects 68 Chinese warplanes, 10 Navy vessels near island

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet with billionaire Elon Musk during his upcoming trip to the United States. The agenda for the meeting has not been disclosed. However, Musk has recently faced accusations of allowing antisemitic messages on his social media platform, X.
articles.title: Israel's Netanyahu to meet Elon Musk as company faces antisemitism controversy

articles.description: Talks between the leaders of Serbia and Kosovo on improving ties failed to make a breakthrough Thursday, after Pristina rejected an EU compromise proposal, the bloc's foreign policy chief said. Kosovo insists it wants Serbia to make the first move by taking steps towards officially recognising its independence.
articles.title: EU fails to find breakthrough in Serbia, Kosovo talks

articles.description: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is set to announce new restrictions on the use of artificial intelligence (AI) technology. While the agency has successfully utilized AI in drug busts and crime prevention, DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas stresses the importance of responsible and trustworthy use of AI that safeguards privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties.
articles.title: US Homeland Security Department reveals new AI guardrails as it deploys technology across agency

articles.description: The United Nations said Thursday that most of the thousands of deaths in Libya's flood disaster could have been averted if early warning and emergency management systems had functioned properly. If the system in Libya ad worked properly, "the emergency management forces would have been able to carry out the evacuation of the people, and we could have avoided most of the human casualties," WMO chief Petteri Taalas told reporters in Geneva.
articles.title: Most Libya flood casualties could have been avoided: UN

articles.description: Survivors of a migrant shipwreck off Greece in June have filed a lawsuit against the Greek authorities, accusing them of failing to protect the lives of those on board. The overcrowded fishing trawler, carrying between 400-750 people from Pakistan, Syria, and Egypt, sank in international waters. Only 104 men survived, and 82 bodies were recovered.
articles.title: Survivors of migrant shipwreck file lawsuit against Greek authorities

articles.description: A Palestinian family in Libya, who had fled Gaza during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, has been affected by the devastating floods in the country. Two members of the Abu Amra family have died, and 12 others are missing after the storm caused dams to burst and destroyed a quarter of the city of Derna.
articles.title: Palestinian family that fled wars suffers deaths in Libya

articles.author: Kelsey Ables, Victoria Bisset, Tobi Raji
articles.description: North Korea’s leader visited a Russian city near the China-North Korea border. A Russian strike injured five people in Kharkiv.
articles.title: Ukraine live briefing: Kim Jong Un views missiles in Vladivostok; first vessels use Ukraine’s new shipping corridor

articles.author: Ellen Francis, Jintak Han
articles.description: UNESCO listed as “in danger” historical sites in Ukraine’s Kyiv and Lviv as World Heritage sites. They include St. Sophia’s Cathedral and the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra.
articles.title: In photos: Centuries-old Kyiv cathedral and monastery on U.N. danger list

articles.author: Victoria Bisset
articles.description: The protest movement in Iran against the “morality police” began with the death of a young Iranian woman a year ago.
articles.title: The story of Iran’s Mahsa Amini uprising told through its most iconic images

articles.author: Mary Beth Sheridan, Matthew Brown
articles.description: Mexican troops captured Guzmán in January in a gun battle that killed least 29. He faces charges related to drug trafficking, money laundering and weapons.
articles.title: Ovidio Guzmán, alleged fentanyl boss and son of El Chapo, sent to U.S.

articles.author: Ellen Nakashima, Cate Cadell
articles.description: The expected purge of Li Shangfu comes after the foreign minister and two top military leaders were sacked, heightening concerns about how China’s foreign policy is being managed.
articles.title: China’s defense minister under investigation for corruption

articles.author: Louisa Loveluck
articles.description: The Sadaawi family had gathered for a wedding in the coastal Libyan city of Soussa. Then the floods came.
articles.title: A Libyan family recounts how they survived the deadly floods

articles.author: Miriam Berger
articles.description: The last year gave the world a glimpse of the seething anger just below the surface of Iran’s repressive society. But it also highlighted the resilience of the regime.
articles.title: A year after Mahsa Amini’s death: Repression and defiance in Iran

articles.author: Andrew Jeong, Min Joo Kim, Victoria Bisset, Natalia Abbakumova, Adam Taylor
articles.description: Kim Jong Un continues his Russia trip. President Volodymyr Zelensky seeks to persuade U.S. lawmakers to approve a $24 billion assistance package for Ukraine.
articles.title: Ukraine live briefing: Kim Jong Un visits jet factory in Russia; Zelensky to head to Washington

articles.author: Benjamin Soloway
articles.description: In the aftermath of an earthquake in Morocco, many who rely on tourism, an industry already beleaguered by the coronavirus epidemic, fear for their livelihoods.
articles.title: Quake tourism slump could cut lifeline to Morocco’s mountain villages

articles.author: Adela Suliman
articles.description: Princess Diana’s black sheep sweater, made by Warm and Wonderful and worn in 1981, is now “the most valuable sweater ever sold at auction,” Sotheby’s said.
articles.title: Princess Diana’s ‘black sheep’ sweater breaks auction records

articles.author: Tim Johnson
articles.description: His emblematic oversized figures, evoking vanity, pomposity and greed, brought global attention to Latin American art.
articles.title: Fernando Botero, Colombian artist of rotund and whimsical imagery, dies at 91

articles.author: Michael E. Miller
articles.description: Luxury brands use crocodile leather for their pricey products. For Indigenous Australians, that creates an opportunity.
articles.title: The hunt for wild crocodile eggs that feeds the designer handbag craze

articles.author: Kelsey Ables, Jennifer Hassan
articles.description: The virus has killed two so far and infected at least five in the state of Kerala and is considered a priority disease by the WHO for its epidemic potential.
articles.title: What is Nipah virus? India rushes to contain outbreak.

articles.author: Nilo Tabrizy
articles.description: A year after Mahsa Amini’s death, family members of protesters killed in Iran are systematically surveilled and detained by the authorities.
articles.title: Their loved ones were killed in Iran’s uprising. Then the state came for them.

articles.author: María Paúl
articles.description: Argentina’s Federal Police raided a man’s home Tuesday, conducting the country’s largest seizure of materials espousing Nazi propaganda in recent years.
articles.title: Argentina takes down ‘prolific’ clandestine Nazi printing press

articles.author: Francesca Ebel
articles.description: Before the plane crash that killed mercenary boss Yevgeniy Prigozhin, a consolidation of military leaders running Vladimir Putin’s war in Ukraine was already underway.
articles.title: Shuffle of Russian military chiefs preceded death of Wagner boss Prigozhin

articles.author: Ishaan Tharoor
articles.description: Libya’s two regimes left critical infrastructure in a state of neglect. But the intervention of myriad outside powers laid the groundwork for disaster.
articles.title: Libya’s catastrophe is everyone’s fault

articles.author: Karen DeYoung
articles.description: The Biden administration is withholding an $85 million weapons financing package to Cairo over human rights concerns.
articles.title: U.S. cuts military aid to Egypt, sends money instead to Taiwan

articles.author: Bryan Pietsch, Annabelle Timsit, Adam Taylor, Mikhail Klimentov
articles.description: “Neither Elon Musk, nor any private citizen, can have the last word when it comes to U.S. national security,” said the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
articles.title: Ukraine live briefing: Putin accepts Kim’s invitation to visit North Korea; Senate probing Starlink vulnerabilities

articles.author: Louisa Loveluck, Sarah Dadouch, Kareem Fahim
articles.description: A Washington Post team was among the first to reach the devastated city of Derna, in Libya’s flood-battered east, where the death toll could reach 20,000.
articles.title: In Libya’s flood-shattered east, a disaster of ‘mythic proportions’

articles.author: Widlore Mérancourt, Samantha Schmidt, Amanda Coletta
articles.description: The neighbors share the Caribbean island of Hispaniola and a long history of strained relations.
articles.title: Dominican Republic closes border with Haiti, further stoking tensions

articles.author: Les Carpenter
articles.description: Three months after raiding Paris 2024 headquarters, France’s top financial prosecutor says no significant corruption has been found in contract rigging investigation.
articles.title: No significant corruption found in Paris Olympic raid, prosecutor says

articles.author: Scott Dance, Marina Dias, Theodora Yu
articles.description: The globe’s remarkable warmth — especially of its oceans, most of which have been running several degrees warmer than normal for months — served as a backdrop for all of the floods.
articles.title: What this month’s deadly floods tell us about our global climate future

articles.author: Victoria Bisset
articles.description: Isa Balado was on air when a man appeared to touch her buttocks and the host urged her to “put this idiot on.”
articles.title: Spanish journalist confronts man who she says groped her on live TV

articles.author: Anthony Faiola
articles.description: Arrivals in Italy have surged to 123,800 so far this year — roughly double last year’s figures, and on track to match or exceed the 2016 record.
articles.title: Italy’s Meloni campaigned on stopping immigration. It’s not working.

articles.description: The company outlined its latest deal, which was released Thursday.
articles.title: Stellantis offers raises, inflation protection measures to UAW as strikes continue

articles.description: Croatia's Rimac Nevera tops out at 258 mph thanks to its four motors and 1,914 horsepower. It's also stunningly easy to drive.
articles.title: Take a look at the powerful and easy-to-drive $2.1 million Rimac Nevera electric hypercar

articles.description: The United Auto Workers strike is bringing a blue-collar versus billionaire battle to Detroit, just as UAW President Shawn Fain wanted.
articles.title: UAW strike brings blue-collar vs. billionaire battle to Detroit

articles.description: About 12,700 workers will be on strike at three Ford, GM and Stellantis facilities, the UAW said.
articles.title: UAW members go on strike at three key auto plants after deal deadline passes

articles.description: CEO Chris Rondeau has been been with Planet Fitness for more than three decades.
articles.title: Planet Fitness shares sink after board ousts CEO in shocking move

articles.description: Their questions follow the publication of a biography of Elon Musk with an anecdote suggesting SpaceX disconnected Starlink service before a Ukrainian attack.
articles.title: Senators ask Pentagon for answers on SpaceX’s Starlink service in Ukraine

articles.description: Grocery delivery platform Instacart raised its initial price range to between $28 and $30 per share in a regulatory filing Friday.
articles.title: Instacart aims for valuation of up to $10 billion in upcoming IPO

articles.description: Arm began trading Thursday with shares in its blockbuster IPO priced at $51 each, valuing the company at about $54.5 billion.
articles.title: Arm's second trading day is more subdued, but valuation still tops $60 billion

articles.description: French supermarket chain Carrefour added labels to products that have shrunk in size but cost more, putting pressure on suppliers that have increased prices.
articles.title: French grocery chain adds 'shrinkflation' labels to products in bid to shame supplier pricing

articles.description: Here's how far the stocks have fallen since the meme stock moment shown in the new movie "Dumb Money."
articles.title: The meme stock mania is now a movie. Here's what has happened to GameStop and AMC

articles.description: Oil prices climbed to their highest level of the year this week, extending a rally that has put a return to $100 a barrel sharply into focus.
articles.title: Oil just hit its highest level of the year — and some analysts expect a return to $100 before 2024

articles.description: Iranian authorities appear to be bracing for a resurgence of popular anger on the anniversary of Mahsa Amini's death in police custody.
articles.title: More repression, yet more resistance: Iran one year after the Mahsa Amini protests

articles.description: There are tentative signs of a bounceback in global trade, according to the CEO of shipping titan Maersk.
articles.title: Shipping giant Maersk is seeing tentative signs of a bounce back in global trade

articles.description: Yum China is spending more on tech, an investment that's allowed it to open more stores without having to hire more staff, CEO Joey Wat told CNBC.
articles.title: Yum China says tech investments let it open more stores without needing more staff

articles.description: China's retail sales and industrial production picked up pace in August with better-than-expected growth, according to National Bureau of Statistics data.
articles.title: China’s retail sales surprise with faster growth in August, but real estate drag worsens

articles.description: South Korean media reported that Lisa rejected a 50 billion won offer from YG Entertainment.
articles.title: Shares of K-pop agency plunge 9% after Blackpink member reportedly rejects contract renewal offer

articles.description:
Sept. 8-14, 2023

Protesters celebrate the Catalan National Day in Barcelona. Rescuers search for survivors after a deadly earthquake in Morocco. Thousands of migrants arrive to Lampedusa on small, unseaworthy boats. In sports, Italy faces Ukraine in their qualifying soccer match for the Euro 2024.

This gallery highlights some of the most compelling images made or published in the past week by Associated Press photographers in Europe and Africa.

The selection was curated by AP photographer Alessandra Tarantino in Rome.

Scientists in Colombia are breeding mosquitoes to fight dengue fever, Chileans marked the 50 year anniversary of a coup that ushered in a brutal military dictatorship, forward Jenni Hermoso, who has accused now-suspended president of the Spanish soccer federation Luis Rubiales of sexual assault, returned to Mexico to rejoin her soccer club in Pachuca.

articles.description:
Images taken by satellite show the physical devastation from a flood that killed at least 11,300 people in the eastern Libyan city of Derna. 

Two dams above Derna burst early Monday under the pressure from rain dropped by a storm. The pent-up water swept blocks of low-lying downtown Derna out to the Mediterranean Sea. 

Many said they heard loud explosions as the dams exploded. A flood several meters (many feet) high rolled down a mountainside into the city. 

Images made about 400 miles above the earth’s surface show that the storm left a brown layer of mud and dirt across the city.

Untold numbers are buried under mud and debris that includes overturned cars and chunks of concrete. The death toll soared to 11,300 as search efforts continue, Marie el-Drese, secretary-general of the Libyan Red Crescent, told The Associated Press by phone Thursday.

She said that an additional 10,100 had been reported missing. Health authorities previously put the death toll in Derna at 5,500.

The...
articles.title: AP PHOTOS: Satellite images show flood devastation that killed more than 11,000 in Libya

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis on Saturday announced a further 300 million euros to fight the effects of climate change, acknowledging the scale of the crisis facing the country.

articles.author: Sébastian SEIBT
articles.description: Chinese Defence Minister Li Shangfu has not been seen in public for more than two weeks. The disappearance of this top official close to President Xi Jinping comes two months after that of now-former foreign affairs minister Qin Gang, and follows the dismissal of a pair of influential military generals. For some observers, Li's vanishing is likely linked to corruption, while others see it as a sign of intense political battles hidden from outside eyes.
articles.title: Questions swirl around Xi’s motives after a second top minister disappears in China

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The US state of California sued five of the world's largest oil companies on Friday, alleging the firms caused billions of dollars in damages and misled the public by minimizing the risks from fossil fuels, according to a court filing.

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: An Egyptian court has sentenced prominent dissident Hisham Kassem to six months in prison, his lawyer and political movement said, a move barring him from taking part in campaigning for next year's presidential election.

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The G77+China, a group of developing and emerging countries representing 80 percent of the world's population, kicked off a summit in Cuba Friday with a call to "change the rules of the game" of the global order.

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Remote villages in Morocco's Atlas mountains were among the areas hit hardest by the earthquake that struck Morocco last week. Traditional mudbrick houses, which were ill-suited to withstand the strong tremors, cracked or collapsed, killing many inhabitants and leaving survivors homeless. FRANCE 24's Luke Shrago, Tarek Kai and Abdallah Malkawi visited Tolkin, a village located 80 kilometres from Marrakech, as a new truck loaded with supplies arrived to help the stricken population.
articles.title: Aid is slow to arrive to remote Moroccan villages following quake

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: The first cargo ships have sailed to Ukraine to load grain following the collapse of a deal with Russia, Ukrainian deputy PM said on Saturday. Earlier, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un inspected Russian nuclear-capable bombers and other warplanes in Russia’s Far East. Follow our live blog for all the latest developments on the war in Ukraine. Read our live blog to see how all the day's events unfolded. All times are Paris time (GMT+2).
articles.title: First cargo ships sail to Ukraine after grain deal collapse, Kyiv says

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Mexico on Friday extradited the son of Sinaloa Cartel kingpin Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman to the United States to face narcotics charges, US Attorney General Merrick Garland said.

articles.description: Iranians at home and abroad marked the first anniversary Saturday of the death in police custody of Mahsa Amini, with activists speaking of a renewed crackdown to prevent any resurgence of the protests which rocked the country last year.

articles.description: One year ago this Saturday, 22-year-old Mahsa Amini died after being arrested by Iran’s morality police for wearing her hijab "improperly". Her death led to massive anti-regime protests, known by their now-iconic slogan: “Woman, Life, Freedom”. The Observers team has been in regular contact with dozens of women across Iran over the past 12 months. Many of them have told us that it has become the “new normal” for millions of women in Iran to go out in public with their hair uncovered. But with a new law under discussion that would massively increase the penalties for hijab-related offenses, how long will these new freedoms last?
articles.title: Proposed hijab penalties in Iran: 'They can’t prosecute millions of women'

articles.description: Georgian Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili commemorated on Tuesday the victims of a brief war with Russia 15 years ago and lamented the loss of the breakaway regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia. "This was a terrible tragedy," Garibashvili said on the anniversary of the start of the South Caucasus war, which lasted from August 8 to 12, 2008. He said 400 Georgians were killed and more than 2,000 injured. To this day, Moscow supports the breakaway Georgian regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia and has stationed Russian troops in the region. Garibashvili said that the Black Sea republic was sti...
articles.title: Georgian premier marks 15-year anniversary of brief war with Russia

articles.author: Reuters UK
articles.description: By Boureima Balima and Abdel-Kader Mazou NIAMEY (Reuters) -Niger's junta on Tuesday rejected the latest diplomatic mission from West African countries aimed at restoring constitutional order after a July 26 coup, resisting pressure from the United States and the United Nations to come to the negotiating table. Heads of state from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) are preparing for a summit on Thursday to discuss their standoff with the junta, which defied an Aug. 6 deadline to reinstate ousted President Mohamed Bazoum. ECOWAS defence chiefs agreed on Friday on a possible m...
articles.title: Niger junta rebuffs latest diplomatic mission as high-stakes summit looms

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description: Kia is clearly serious about offering a top notch electric and it has unleashed the plush EV9 to prove it. After achieving a degree of success with the EV6 two years ago, the Koreans have upped the ante with an imposing and well-equipped EV9, albeit it at a high price. The first lavishly equipped Launch Edition with all-wheel drive will bend your bank balance to the tune of €83,190 in Europe. Prices for the base version with no gizmos hover around €70,000. The snub-nosed EV9 is big but not brutish. It stands at 5 metres from bumper to bumper in length and is designed to lure SUV buyers as well...
articles.title: Kia hits the big time with Range Rover-beating electric EV9

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
London-based sex worker Marin Scarlett and right-wing populist Nigel Farage might initially appear unlikely campaigning allies, but when it comes to the pitfalls of banking in Britain they share a common cause.
"It's ridiculous that financial institutions can act like moral arbiters," Scarlett told AFP, echoing Farage's exact same criticism last month after a scandal erupted around his treatment by British banks.
Farage's complaints about the closure of his account with the upmarket Coutts, a subsidiary of NatWest used by the late Queen Elizabeth II, dominated the news for days, prompted questions in parliament and cost top executives their jobs.
For Scarlett, who is in her thirties and started out as a sex worker 15 years ago, the sudden uproar was galling, given arbitrary account closure…
articles.title: 'Stigmatized': Sex workers join criticism of UK banks

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The second-ranking US diplomat met Niger's military leaders on Monday to press to reverse a coup but reported no headway a day after an ultimatum from the West African bloc ECOWAS was ignored.
Victoria Nuland, a veteran envoy and acting deputy secretary of state, said she met for more than two hours with military chiefs who ousted democratically elected Western ally Mohamed Bazoum on July 26.
Nuland's trip, conducted in secrecy until she left, came after the expiration of a deadline set by ECOWAS to reinstate Bazoum by midnight (2300 GMT) on Sunday or risk military intervention.
The 15-nation bloc is reconvening for its own diplomatic push on the crisis with a summit Thursday in Nigerian capital Abuja.
A source close to ECOWAS said an immediate military intervention to restore Bazoum was n…
articles.title: US envoy meets Niger coup leaders but sees no headway

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Mourners and fans gathered Tuesday in the Irish town once home to singer Sinead O'Connor to pay their last respects ahead of her burial.
The musician's funeral cortege will pass along the seafront in the town of Bray, 20 kilometers (13 miles) south of Dublin, where she lived for 15 years.
The Grammy award-winning singer, best known for her cover of "Nothing Compares 2 U", died last month after being found unresponsive at her London home. She was 56.
The musician, who rose to international fame in the 1990s, will be mourned at a funeral attended by family and friends before a private burial.
Her family offered the public the chance to pay their final respects by organizing the cortege through Bray, saying she loved the town and its residents.
"With this procession her family would like to a…
articles.title: Ireland bids farewell to singer Sinead O'Connor

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
ISLAMABAD (Reuters) — Pakistan's jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan appealed against his conviction and three-year sentence on corruption charges on Tuesday, his lawyer said, a ruling which analysts say is likely to fuel political instability. 
Naeem Panjutha said the petition challenging the weekend conviction had been filed in Islamabad High Court which will hear the case on Wednesday. Ex-cricketer Khan, 70, was jailed on charges of selling state gifts unlawfully during his tenure as premier from 2018 to 2022.
articles.title: Jailed ex-Pakistan PM Imran Khan challenges graft conviction

articles.author: Miami Herald
articles.description: As a kidnapped American nurse and her child marked their 11th day in captivity in Haiti on Monday, the United Nations’ leading child-welfare agency says it is seeing an alarming spike in the abductions of women and children in the Caribbean nation. Nearly 300 cases have been reported in the first six months of this year, UNICEF said. The number is close to the total documented in 2022 and is close to three times more than what was recorded in 2021. In Haiti, most kidnappings are at the hands of armed gangs, whose warfare has worsened since the 2021 assassination of the country’s president, Jov...
articles.title: Kidnappings of women, children spiking in Haiti where a US nurse, daughter remain captive

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: By Claudia Martini and Miguel Lo Bianco BUENOS AIRES (Reuters) - Argentines, who have seen jobs and wages hit by economic malaise and rampant inflation, lined up at churches on Monday to ask St. Cayetano, the patron saint of bread and labor, for employment, with some critical of politicians for not doing enough to help. The South American country, which saw unemployment tick up to 6.9% in the first quarter, is set for primary elections on Sunday where the conservative opposition is expected to outperform the ruling Peronist coalition. The run-up to the vote, in effect a dress rehearsal for the...
articles.title: Hard-hit Argentina workers ask saints, not politicians, for jobs

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Crouching beside Ukrainian-made attack drones on a runway, TV star Serhiy Prytula appeared keen to taunt Moscow with a crowdfunded fleet that experts have linked with recent strikes inside Russia.
Ukraine has not taken direct responsibility for the string of attacks, including on the capital Moscow, but President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned that "war" is coming to Russia.
Polls show the former stand-up comedian's crowdfunding campaigns for the military have rendered him one of the country's most trusted public figures -- second only to Zelensky.
Offering a rare glimpse at Ukraine's homegrown explosive drones, Prytula recently shared images of himself with a fleet in an undisclosed location.
"Muscovites! Shudder from the sirens. Go to the bomb shelters," he wrote on social media alongside…
articles.title: 'From Ukrainians without love': Drone fundraiser taunts Moscow

articles.author: Common Dreams
articles.description:
Local, national, and global leaders warned of the dangers of nuclear weapons as they commemorated the 78th anniversary of the dropping of an atomic bomb on the city of Hiroshima Sunday.
This year's anniversary comes as the release of the film Oppenheimer has offered a high-profile reminder of the history of the atomic bomb and as nuclear tensions in the current day have heightened, in part due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. At the start of the year, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists moved their doomsday clock to 90 seconds to midnight.
"Leaders around the world must confront the reality that nuclear threats now being voiced by certain policymakers reveal the folly of nuclear deterrence theory," Hiroshima Mayor Kazumi Matsui said during his peace address at the commemoration ceremony …
articles.title: On 78th anniversary of Hiroshima bombing, mayor decries 'folly' of deterrence theory

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Organisers of the World Scout Jamboree asked host South Korea Monday to "urgently" evacuate tens of thousands of children from their campsite ahead of a typhoon, just days after a heatwave caused mass scout illnesses.
Typhoon Khanun, which killed at least two people in Japan, is due to make landfall in South Korea on Thursday, near where some 43,000 scouts have been camping in North Jeolla province for their problem-plagued jamboree.
Korean media have called the jamboree "a national disgrace" after an extreme heatwave caused hundreds of scouts to fall ill and prompted American and British scout groups to withdraw as criticism grew over conditions at the campsite.
Organisers had insisted the event would continue but on Monday the World Organization of the Scout Movement said Seoul had told …
articles.title: After heatwave, typhoon forces South Korea to evacuate scout jamboree

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
More than 3,000 US military personnel have arrived in the Red Sea aboard two warships, as part of increased deployments after tanker seizures by Iran, the US Navy said Monday.
The US sailors and Marines entered the Red Sea on Sunday after transiting through the Suez Canal in a pre-announced deployment, the US Navy's Fifth Fleet said in a statement.
They arrived on board the USS Bataan and USS Carter Hall warships, providing "greater flexibility and maritime capability" to the Fifth Fleet, the statement added.
The US military says Iran has either seized or attempted to take control of nearly 20 internationally flagged ships in the region over the past two years.
USS Bataan is an amphibious assault ship which can carry fixed-wing and rotary aircraft as well as landing craft. The USS Carter H…
articles.title: Thousands of US sailors, Marines reach Red Sea after Iran tensions

articles.author: Guy Taylor
articles.description: President Biden will attempt to stiffen international resolve and unity behind Ukraine and confront head on the rising global threats of authoritarian military aggression and autocracy during a major speech at the U.N. General Assembly next week.

Franchetti focused on the service's shipbuilding plans and maintenance headaches that have resulted in canceled deployments and reduced flying hours.
articles.title: Milestone Navy nominee faces some familiar questions at Senate grilling

articles.description: Britain, France and Germany announced Thursday they will keep their sanctions on Iran related to the Mideast country's atomic program and development of ballistic missiles. The measures were to expire in October under a timetable spelled out in the now defunct nuclear deal between Tehran and world powers.
articles.title: Britain, France and Germany say they will keep their nuclear and missiles sanctions on Iran

articles.description:
A new report published by Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse (TRAC) has revealed 125,000 migrants settled in New York between April to June 2023, higher than any city in the US. 

According to the New York Post, NYC's taxpayers are estimated to spend $US40,000 per migrant by the end of this financial year, if it continues to receive asylum seekers at the current average rate. 

Mayor Eric Adams warned residents of a "financial tsunami" and said the crisis could cost the city $US12 billion over the next three years. 

The Big Apple's expenditure on asylum seekers is already bigger than the entire budget of the city of Boston.

New York's 1980s-era ‘right to shelter’ law, which requires the city to house and feed anyone who asks, has been blamed for the unhinged influx of migrants.
articles.title: New York taxpayers set to spend more on migrants than anywhere in the US

articles.description:
The UK government has revealed 80 prison officers did not attend their expected shift the day a terror suspect escaped.

Former soldier Daniel Abed escaped from a London prison strapped under a food delivery truck last Wednesday.

The government says despite the absent officers, overall staffing levels were still above the minimum requirement.

They maintain the numbers were not behind the security breach.

The absentee officers make up 40 per cent of the staff meant to be on shift.
articles.title: 80 officers absent the day prisoner escaped in UK

articles.description:
There are fears up to 20,000 people have died after flooding through eastern Libya. 

Hope is turning to despair for residents in the city of Derna as survivors continue to wade through the rubble in search of loved ones.

Questions are being raised about what could have been done to prevent the loss of life.

Satellite images from before and after the floods show the levels of immense destruction.

The hostilities in recent years have split the city into sections as rescue crews face a difficult task of bringing relief to as many places as possible.
articles.title: Libya floods death toll rises above 20,000 as survivors continue searching

articles.description: Hunter Biden, the son of Joe Biden has been formally indicted days after an impeachment inquiry was launched into the US President.

Even residents whose cellars remain flooded are glad the water came and the Russian troops did not.

A visitor passes the Raytheon Technologies Corporation (RTX) logo at Le Bourget Airport near Paris, France, on 22 June 2023 (Reuters)

 
The Cradle: US-Saudi arms 'megadeal' collapses over Russia, China links: Report 
A major US weapons maker called off a multibillion-dollar deal over their Saudi partner's alleged collaboration with Russian and Chinese companies 
US weapons maker RTX, formerly known as Raytheon Technologies, scrubbed a multibillion deal with Saudi firm Scopa Defense earlier this year over “concerns” that the latter was pursuing business with sanctioned Russian and Chinese companies, according to people familiar with the deal that spoke with the Wall Street Journal (WSJ).

 
Read more ....

Update #2: US arms maker cancels deal with Saudi firm over alleged ties to Russia, China: Report (Press TV)

 
WNU Editor: This deal involved installing radars and multiple air defense systems in Saudi Arabia  with an investment of $25 billion in the kingdom and $17 worth of sales.
articles.title: US-Saudi Arms 'Megadeal' Collapses Over The Kingdom's Ties To Russia And China

articles.description:
NBC News: Hunter Biden indicted on federal gun charges

 
The president's son was indicted after a plea agreement on tax and gun charges fell apart in July and as House Republicans investigate his finances.  
Federal prosecutors have indicted Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, on gun charges, court documents show. 
Biden was indicted Thursday in federal court in Delaware on three counts tied to possession of a gun while using narcotics. 
Two counts accuse Biden of having completed a form indicating he was not using illegal drugs when he bought a Colt Cobra revolver in October 2018. The third count alleges he possessed a firearm while using a narcotic. The indictment says Biden certified on a federally mandated form "that he was not an unlawful user of, and addicted to, any stimulant, narcotic drug, and any other controlled substance, when in fact, as he knew, that statement was false and fictitious.” 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: I for one would not be surprised if these charges are dismissed before trial. Robert Barnes legal and political analysis is probably correct (see tweet below).

Goal here is to tie up Hunter such that he can't be subpoenaed to testify in any impeachment effort, and can claim the 5th. It's not a real effort to punish. https://t.co/wranfhrVkz
— Robert Barnes (@barnes_law) September 14, 2023
  

President Biden's Son Hunter Biden Has Been Indicted On Gun Charges

 
Hunter Biden is indicted on federal firearm-purchasing charges after plea deal fails -- AP
 
Biden's son Hunter hit with gun charge, first for a US president's child -- Reuters
 
Hunter Biden indicted on gun charges after plea deal falls apart -- The Guardian
articles.title: President Biden's Son Hunter Biden Has Been Indicted On Gun Charges

articles.description:
Politico: Zelenskyy to visit Washington after UN appearance 
The Ukrainian president will meet with President Joe Biden and key members of Congress, a person familiar with the plans confirmed. 
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will meet with President Joe Biden and key members of Congress in Washington next week, a person familiar with the plans confirmed to POLITICO on Thursday evening. 
Zelenskyy’s stop-off in Washington will follow his attendance at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, where he hopes to shore up support for his country in the war against Russia.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The Ukraine government needs another massive infusion of US military and economic aid. This is why this trip and visit has been hastily arranged at the last minute.

articles.description:
Kim Jong Un visits an aircraft manufacturing plant. TASS 

 
Bloomberg: Kim Jong Un Tours Russia Jet Plant as Kremlin Denies Arms Deals 
North Korean leader toured a Russian factory that makes fighter jets, as the US warned he is on a visit that could support the Kremlin’s assault on Ukraine. 
Kim arrived in the eastern city of Komsomolsk-on-Amur on Friday to see a facility that makes high-tech fighter jets and other aircraft. 
He was shown planes including the Su-35 as well as the Su-57 stealth combat fighter, according to a Russian government Telegram channel. 
Kim’s limousine was later shown on social media being loaded onto the personal armored train that took him to Russia.

 
Read more ....

North Korea's Kim Gets a Close Look at Russian Fighter Jets as His Tour Narrows Its Focus to Weapons -- AP

articles.description:
Chinese Defense Minister Li Shangfu (far left) attends the 20th IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in June. | REUTERS

 
Reuters: Exclusive-Chinese defence minister under investigation for corrupt procurement 
Defence Minister Li Shangfu, who has been missing from public view for more than two weeks, has been placed under investigation by Chinese authorities, according to 10 people familiar with the matter. 
The investigation into Li relates to procurement of military equipment, according to a regional security official and three people in direct contact with the Chinese military. 
Reuters was unable to obtain details on which equipment purchases were under scrutiny. 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: There has been no confirmation from the Chinese government or media on the whereabouts of Defence Minister Li Shangfu. But this definitely does not look good. 
Chinese Defence Minister Under Investigation For Corruption

 
China's defence minister under investigation for corrupt procurement, being removed from post: Reports -- CNA 
Missing Chinese defense chief signals turmoil in Xi's government -- Japan Times
 
Li Shangfu: Top US envoy questions China defence minister’s absence -- BBC
 
Speculation grows over whereabouts of China’s Defense Minister Li Shangfu -- CNN
articles.title: Chinese Defence Minister Under Investigation For Corruption

articles.description:
Reuters: China sanctions Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin for arms sales to Taiwan 
BEIJING (Reuters) -China will impose sanctions against U.S. aerospace and defence firms Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin for providing weapons to Taiwan, the Chinese foreign ministry said on Friday. 
The sanctions are being enacted under China's Anti-Foreign Sanctions Law, ministry spokesperson Mao Ning told a regular press briefing. 
"We urge the U.S. side to effectively abide by the one-China principle... cease U.S.-Taiwan military liaison and stop arming Taiwan, or else it will be subject to a resolute and forceful retaliation by the Chinese side," she said. 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: We in the West are always reading and hearing reports on how the West is trying to decouple from China. What we do not read or hear about is China trying to decouple from the West.

China Sanctions Northrop Grumman And Lockheed Martin For Arms Sales To Taiwan

 
China to impose sanctions on two U.S. companies over Taiwan arms sales -- Xinhua 
China sanctions two US defence companies over Taiwan arms sales -- CNA/AFP
 
China Hits Two US Military Firms With Symbolic Moves Over Taiwan -- Bloomberg
China Sanctions Lockheed Martin And Northrop Grumman Concerning Arms Sales To Taiwan: Report -- Benzinga
articles.title: China Sanctions Northrop Grumman And Lockheed Martin For Arms Sales To Taiwan

articles.description:
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, left, meets with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi at Al Ittihadiya Palace in Cairo, Egypt, in January 2023 [File: Khaled Desouki/Pool via AP Photo]

 
Washington Post: U.S. cuts military aid to Egypt, sends money instead to Taiwan 
The Biden administration this week told Congress that it intends to withhold $85 million designated for U.S. security assistance to Egypt this year, and instead provide the bulk of the money to Taiwan. 
The decision brought immediate criticism from lawmakers that the reprogrammed amount either wasn’t enough to punish Egypt for ongoing detentions of political prisoners and other human rights abuses, or that it was a paltry offering to Taiwan given the urgency of China’s aggressive behavior. 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The amount of money involved is $85 million, and no one is happy with this move. US lawmakers believe this is not enough to punish Egypt for its human rights abuses, and others believe this money is a paltry sum to help Taiwan. And as for Egypt, the aid is still continuing .... US to send more military aid to Egypt despite rights concerns (Al-Monitor). 
U.S. Cuts Military Aid To Egypt And Will Send This Aid To Taiwan

 
US will redirect millions of funds for Egypt to Taiwan and Lebanon -- CNN
 
US to withhold $85m military aid to Egypt over political prisoners, rights -- Al Jazeera
 
U.S. to redirect millions in military aid for Egypt to Taiwan -- Axios
articles.title: U.S. Cuts Military Aid To Egypt And Will Send This Aid To Taiwan

articles.description:
SpaceX-Ukraine Saga Ends As Pentagon Engages Elon Musk's Company © Provided by Benzinga

 
CNBC: Air Force chief sounds off on Musk’s Ukraine decision, tensions with China and the future of war 
* Air Force Secretary Frank Kendall said that last year Elon Musk’s SpaceX was making “unilateral decisions” about its Starlink service in Ukraine. 
* The Air Force chief said the growing importance of space has increased collaboration between the military and the private sector. 
* He said the Air Force, like many parts of the government and private sector, is looking for ways to use AI. 
U.S. Air Force Secretary Frank Kendall does not shy away from commenting on controversy — even as it relates to the world’s richest person and a key Department of Defense contractor. 
Kendall weighed in Tuesday after SpaceX CEO Elon Musk acknowledged withholding Starlink satellite service to Ukraine as it planned a surprise attack on Russian forces last year. 
The disclosure sparked criticism of Musk, and Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., called for a probe into SpaceX.
The Air Force works with the company on a variety of missions, such as national security launches, but did not play a role in the use of Starlink in Ukraine when Musk made the decision last September. 

 
Read more ....

 
Update: Elon Musk’s refusal to provide Starlink support for Ukraine attack in Crimea raises questions for Pentagon (AP)

 
WNU Editor: This article confirms reports that the Pentagon is now in charge of providing Starlink services to Ukraine .... SpaceX-Ukraine Saga Ends As Pentagon Engages Elon Musk's Company (Benzinga).
articles.title: Pentagon Confirms It Has Established A Contract With SpaceX To Deliver Starlink Services In Ukraine

articles.description:
CNN: Taiwan hits back at Elon Musk’s claim that it is ‘part of China’  
Hong Kong CNN  — Taiwan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has hit back after Elon Musk called the self-ruled island an “integral part of China.” 
Speaking remotely at the All-in Summit, which took place in Los Angeles this week, Musk compared Taiwan’s relationship with China to that of Hawaii’s with the United States. 
“[Beijing’s] policy has been to sort of reunite Taiwan with China,” said the Tesla (TSLA) CEO, who claimed he understands China “well.” 

 
Read more .... 
Taiwan Foreign Minister Joseph Wu Slams Elon Musk's Claim That His Country Is A Part Of China
